title: AI-Based Early Academic Performance Prediction System
overview: This project focuses on designing and implementing an artificial intelligence system that predicts student academic performance early in a semester. The system analyzes historical academic records, course enrollment patterns, attendance data, and learning management system engagement metrics to identify students who may be at risk of underperforming. By leveraging supervised machine learning models, the platform generates risk scores and performance forecasts that can be used by faculty and academic advisors to intervene proactively. The project also emphasizes responsible data usage by incorporating privacy-preserving techniques, role-based access control, and transparency in prediction outputs. The overall goal is to support data-driven academic decision-making, improve student retention, and enhance personalized academic support within the Department of Computing.
key_features: Machine learning models for academic performance prediction
Advisor dashboard with risk visualization
Early warning alerts for at-risk students
Secure role-based access to student data
Data preprocessing and feature engineering pipeline

challenges_solutions.challenge: Inconsistent and incomplete academic data across different courses
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented data normalization and feature selection techniques to improve model reliability

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring ethical use of predictive analytics in education
challenges_solutions.solution: Included explainability features and restricted access to sensitive prediction outputs

achievements: Achieved over 85% prediction accuracy during validation
Demonstrated effective early warning capabilities in pilot testing
Presented findings at the ETSU Computing Research Showcase
short_description: An AI-driven system that predicts student academic performance early in the semester using historical records and engagement data, enabling faculty and advisors to provide timely, data-informed academic support.

title: Real-Time Network Intrusion Detection and Alerting Dashboard
overview: This project designs and implements a real-time network intrusion detection and alerting solution tailored for departmental lab environments and small campus networks. The system ingests network traffic logs and flow data, extracts security-relevant features, and applies anomaly detection and signature-based checks to identify suspicious activity such as port scanning, brute-force authentication attempts, and unusual outbound connections. A web-based dashboard provides security analysts and faculty supervisors with a live view of alerts, severity scoring, traffic summaries, and investigation context, including the affected host, timestamps, and correlated events. The platform prioritizes practical deployment by supporting containerized services, configurable detection rules, and a lightweight data pipeline that can run on modest hardware. The goal is to improve visibility into network threats, shorten incident response time, and provide a hands-on cybersecurity learning tool for students.
key_features: Real-time traffic ingestion and feature extraction pipeline
Anomaly detection with configurable alert thresholds
Rule-based detection for common attack patterns
Web dashboard for alert triage and incident context
Severity scoring and alert history for investigations

challenges_solutions.challenge: High volume network events causing alert noise and analyst fatigue
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented aggregation, deduplication, and severity scoring to reduce noisy alerts

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing detection accuracy with low-latency processing requirements
challenges_solutions.solution: Used lightweight feature engineering and streaming-based processing with batching

achievements: Detected simulated intrusion scenarios with high confidence during lab testing
Reduced time-to-triage by consolidating alerts into a single dashboard view
Deployed successfully in a sandbox lab environment for student training
short_description: A real-time intrusion detection and alerting platform that monitors network traffic, identifies suspicious patterns, and provides a live dashboard for incident triage, investigation context, and security analytics.

title: Data-Driven Enrollment Trend Analysis and Forecasting System
overview: This project develops a data analytics platform focused on analyzing historical enrollment data to identify trends and forecast future enrollment patterns across academic programs. The system aggregates multi-year enrollment records, demographic attributes, course demand indicators, and retention statistics to generate insights that support academic planning and resource allocation. Using time-series analysis and predictive modeling techniques, the platform provides forecasts for enrollment growth or decline, highlights seasonal patterns, and identifies factors influencing student enrollment decisions. Interactive visualizations allow department administrators and faculty to explore trends by program, year, and student cohort. The project aims to demonstrate how data science techniques can support strategic decision-making in higher education while providing students with practical experience in data cleaning, modeling, and visualization.
key_features: Multi-year enrollment data aggregation and preprocessing
Time-series forecasting models for enrollment prediction
Interactive dashboards with trend visualizations
Cohort-based analysis by program and demographics
Exportable reports for academic planning

challenges_solutions.challenge: Inconsistent data formats across historical enrollment datasets
challenges_solutions.solution: Built a standardized data ingestion and cleaning pipeline to normalize records

challenges_solutions.challenge: Capturing external factors influencing enrollment trends
challenges_solutions.solution: Incorporated proxy indicators such as course demand and retention rates into models

achievements: Generated enrollment forecasts with strong alignment to historical outcomes
Delivered actionable insights for program-level academic planning
Showcased analytical dashboards during the ETSU Data Science Symposium
short_description: A data analytics and forecasting platform that examines historical enrollment trends and predicts future patterns, helping academic departments make informed decisions about program planning and resource allocation.

title: Digital Workflow Automation for Academic Administrative Processes
overview: This project focuses on designing and implementing an information systems solution that streamlines and automates common academic administrative workflows such as course approvals, student petitions, and faculty requests. The system replaces manual, paper-based processes with a centralized digital platform that supports form submission, approval routing, audit trails, and status tracking. Business process modeling techniques are used to map existing workflows, identify bottlenecks, and redesign processes for efficiency and transparency. The platform provides role-based dashboards for students, faculty, and administrators, enabling each group to view relevant tasks, deadlines, and approval statuses. The project demonstrates how information systems principles can be applied to improve organizational efficiency, data accuracy, and user experience within higher education administrative operations.
key_features: Configurable digital forms and approval workflows
Role-based dashboards for students, faculty, and administrators
Automated notifications and reminders
Audit trail and workflow status tracking
Process analytics for identifying bottlenecks

challenges_solutions.challenge: Capturing diverse workflow requirements across departments
challenges_solutions.solution: Conducted stakeholder interviews and modeled processes using BPMN diagrams

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring system flexibility for future workflow changes
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed a modular workflow engine with configurable rules and stages

achievements: Reduced average approval turnaround time by over 40% in pilot workflows
Improved visibility into administrative process status for stakeholders
Adopted for testing by multiple academic offices
short_description: An information systems platform that digitizes and automates academic administrative workflows, providing role-based dashboards, approval tracking, and process analytics to improve efficiency and transparency across departments.

title: Centralized IT Asset Management and Lifecycle Tracking System
overview: This project involves the design and development of a centralized IT asset management system to help organizations track, manage, and maintain hardware and software assets throughout their lifecycle. The platform records asset acquisition details, assignment history, maintenance schedules, warranty information, and decommissioning status. By consolidating asset data into a single system, IT staff can gain better visibility into inventory usage, reduce asset loss, and improve budgeting and replacement planning. The system includes role-based access for IT administrators, technicians, and department managers, as well as reporting tools that provide insights into asset utilization, aging equipment, and maintenance costs. The project emphasizes practical IT operations management and demonstrates how well-designed systems can improve efficiency and accountability in technology environments.
key_features: Centralized inventory of hardware and software assets
Asset lifecycle tracking from procurement to retirement
Maintenance scheduling and warranty tracking
Role-based access for IT staff and managers
Reporting and analytics for asset utilization

challenges_solutions.challenge: Maintaining accurate and up-to-date asset records across departments
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented asset assignment tracking and mandatory update workflows for changes

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling a wide variety of asset types with different attributes
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed a flexible data model supporting customizable asset fields

achievements: Improved asset visibility and tracking accuracy during pilot deployment
Reduced time spent on manual inventory audits
Provided actionable insights for IT budgeting and replacement planning
short_description: A centralized IT asset management system that tracks hardware and software assets across their entire lifecycle, helping IT teams improve inventory visibility, maintenance planning, and operational efficiency.

title: Scalable Microservices-Based Student Project Repository Platform
overview: This project focuses on building a scalable, microservices-based web platform for managing and showcasing student and faculty projects within the Department of Computing. The system is designed to support project submission, review, discovery, and long-term archival across multiple academic years and departments. By adopting a microservices architecture, the platform separates concerns such as authentication, project metadata management, search and filtering, and media storage, enabling independent scaling and easier maintenance. The project also incorporates role-based access for students, faculty supervisors, and administrators, along with moderation workflows for approving and publishing projects. Emphasis is placed on performance optimization, API design, and maintainability to ensure the platform can grow alongside increasing project volume and user traffic.
key_features: Microservices-based backend architecture
Project submission and approval workflows
Advanced search and filtering across projects
Role-based access for students, faculty, and administrators
Scalable API design for long-term platform growth

challenges_solutions.challenge: Designing services that remain loosely coupled while sharing common data
challenges_solutions.solution: Defined clear service boundaries and used API contracts with shared schemas

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring reliable communication between distributed services
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented RESTful APIs with centralized logging and health monitoring

achievements: Successfully deployed independent services for core platform features
Demonstrated improved scalability over monolithic prototype
Adopted as a reference architecture for future departmental projects
short_description: A scalable, microservices-based platform for submitting, managing, and discovering student and faculty projects, designed to support long-term growth, role-based access, and advanced project search capabilities.

title: Security Posture Assessment and Compliance Monitoring Platform
overview: This project develops a cybersecurity governance, risk, and compliance (GRC) platform that helps organizations continuously assess their security posture against established frameworks such as NIST and CIS Controls. The system collects configuration data, vulnerability scan results, and policy attestations to generate compliance scores and risk summaries. A rules engine maps technical findings to control requirements and highlights gaps that require remediation. The platform includes dashboards for tracking compliance over time, assigning remediation tasks, and producing audit-ready reports. Emphasis is placed on practical applicability, enabling students to understand how technical security findings translate into organizational risk and compliance decisions.
key_features: Continuous security posture assessment mapped to frameworks
Automated compliance scoring and gap analysis
Risk dashboards with trend tracking
Remediation task assignment and status tracking
Audit-ready reporting and exports

challenges_solutions.challenge: Mapping diverse technical findings to multiple compliance frameworks
challenges_solutions.solution: Built a flexible rules engine that links findings to framework controls via metadata

challenges_solutions.challenge: Keeping assessments current without excessive scanning overhead
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented scheduled, incremental data collection and caching strategies

achievements: Generated actionable compliance insights aligned to NIST controls
Reduced manual compliance review effort in simulated audits
Demonstrated end-to-end GRC workflow during capstone review
short_description: A cybersecurity GRC platform that continuously assesses security posture against compliance frameworks, highlights risk gaps, and produces audit-ready reports to support governance and risk management.

title: Predictive Maintenance Analytics for Campus Computing Infrastructure
overview: This project applies data science and machine learning techniques to predict maintenance needs for campus computing infrastructure such as servers, lab machines, and network equipment. The system collects historical maintenance records, system performance metrics, error logs, and usage patterns to identify early warning signs of hardware degradation or failure. By training predictive models on this data, the platform estimates the probability of component failure within a given time window and recommends proactive maintenance actions. Interactive dashboards allow IT staff and administrators to visualize risk levels, prioritize maintenance tasks, and optimize resource allocation. The project demonstrates how data-driven approaches can reduce downtime, extend equipment lifespan, and improve reliability of critical computing resources.
key_features: Data ingestion from system logs and maintenance records
Machine learning models for failure prediction
Risk scoring and maintenance prioritization
Interactive dashboards for infrastructure monitoring
Historical trend analysis and reporting

challenges_solutions.challenge: Limited labeled failure data for rare hardware faults
challenges_solutions.solution: Used anomaly detection and semi-supervised learning to identify early failure patterns

challenges_solutions.challenge: Integrating heterogeneous data sources with varying formats
challenges_solutions.solution: Built a unified data pipeline with schema normalization and feature engineering

achievements: Identified high-risk systems prior to simulated failures
Demonstrated potential reduction in unplanned downtime
Presented predictive analytics results to IT stakeholders
short_description: A data science platform that predicts maintenance needs for campus computing infrastructure using machine learning models trained on system logs, performance metrics, and historical maintenance data.

title: Enterprise Business Intelligence Dashboard for Academic Decision Support
overview: This project delivers an enterprise-grade business intelligence (BI) dashboard designed to support academic and administrative decision-making within the Department of Computing. The system integrates data from multiple sources—including enrollment trends, course performance metrics, graduation outcomes, and faculty workload—to provide a unified, interactive view of key indicators. Data pipelines are built to ensure accuracy, timeliness, and traceability, while the visualization layer emphasizes clarity and drill-down analysis. The platform enables stakeholders to explore trends by year, department, and program, supporting evidence-based planning, resource allocation, and continuous improvement initiatives.
key_features: Integrated data pipelines from academic and administrative sources
Interactive dashboards with drill-down and filtering
KPI tracking for enrollment, retention, and outcomes
Role-based access for administrators and faculty
Exportable reports for meetings and accreditation reviews

challenges_solutions.challenge: Reconciling inconsistent data definitions across sources
challenges_solutions.solution: Established a standardized data model and validation rules

challenges_solutions.challenge: Designing dashboards usable by non-technical stakeholders
challenges_solutions.solution: Applied user-centered design principles and iterative feedback cycles

achievements: Enabled cross-department visibility into academic performance metrics
Reduced manual reporting effort for administrative staff
Supported data-informed planning discussions during pilot reviews
short_description: An enterprise business intelligence dashboard that integrates academic data to support evidence-based decision-making through interactive analytics and clear visualizations.

title: Intelligent Network Monitoring and Performance Visualization System
overview: This project focuses on the design and implementation of an intelligent network monitoring system aimed at improving visibility, reliability, and performance within enterprise and campus networks. The platform collects real-time and historical data from network devices such as switches, routers, and firewalls, including metrics like latency, packet loss, bandwidth utilization, and error rates. By visualizing this data through interactive dashboards and alerts, network administrators can quickly identify bottlenecks, detect abnormal behavior, and respond to outages before they impact users. The system also incorporates basic anomaly detection to highlight unusual traffic patterns and supports configurable thresholds for proactive alerting. This project emphasizes practical networking concepts, systems integration, and operational monitoring.
key_features: Real-time and historical network performance monitoring
Interactive dashboards for traffic and device health visualization
Configurable alerts for performance thresholds
Anomaly detection for unusual traffic patterns
Device-level and network-wide performance summaries

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling high-frequency network data without performance degradation
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented data aggregation and time-based sampling strategies

challenges_solutions.challenge: Presenting complex network metrics in an understandable format
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed layered visualizations with clear summaries and drill-down views

achievements: Enabled faster identification of network performance issues
Improved visibility into bandwidth usage trends
Demonstrated proactive alerting during simulated outages
short_description: An intelligent network monitoring and visualization system that provides real-time insights into network performance, helping administrators detect issues early and maintain reliable connectivity.

title: AI-Powered Academic Advising and Degree Planning Assistant
overview: This project explores the use of artificial intelligence to support academic advising and degree planning for students in computing-related programs. The system analyzes program requirements, completed coursework, academic policies, and student preferences to generate personalized degree plans and course recommendations. Using rule-based logic combined with machine learning techniques, the assistant can identify potential scheduling conflicts, prerequisite issues, and graduation risks early. The platform also provides advisors with summarized student progress reports and scenario-based planning tools to support more informed advising sessions. The project demonstrates how AI can augment, rather than replace, human advisors by improving efficiency, consistency, and student engagement.
key_features: Personalized degree planning and course recommendations
Automated prerequisite and policy compliance checks
Early alerts for graduation risks and scheduling conflicts
Advisor dashboards with student progress summaries
Scenario-based planning for alternative academic paths

challenges_solutions.challenge: Encoding complex and changing degree requirements into the system
challenges_solutions.solution: Developed a modular rules engine that can be updated without retraining models

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing automation with advisor oversight
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed workflows that require advisor review before final recommendations

achievements: Generated accurate degree plans aligned with program requirements
Improved advisor efficiency during simulated advising sessions
Received positive feedback from student usability testing
short_description: An AI-powered academic advising assistant that helps students and advisors create personalized degree plans, identify graduation risks, and explore alternative academic paths using intelligent recommendations.

title: Digital Forensics Case Management and Evidence Tracking System
overview: This project focuses on building a digital forensics case management platform designed to support cybersecurity investigations in academic and enterprise environments. The system allows investigators to create cases, document investigation steps, upload and catalog digital evidence, and maintain strict chain-of-custody records. Evidence items are timestamped, hashed, and linked to specific cases to ensure integrity and accountability throughout the investigation lifecycle. The platform also supports report generation for legal or academic review and includes role-based permissions to restrict access to sensitive case data. Through this project, students gain hands-on experience with forensic workflows, evidence handling principles, and secure system design.
key_features: Case creation and investigation workflow tracking
Digital evidence upload with hashing and timestamps
Chain-of-custody logging for all evidence actions
Role-based access control for investigators and reviewers
Automated case report generation

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring evidence integrity throughout the investigation process
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented cryptographic hashing and immutable audit logs for evidence actions

challenges_solutions.challenge: Managing sensitive data with strict access requirements
challenges_solutions.solution: Applied fine-grained role-based permissions and secure storage practices

achievements: Demonstrated secure chain-of-custody handling during mock investigations
Produced audit-ready forensic reports
Used as a teaching tool in cybersecurity forensics coursework
short_description: A digital forensics case management system that securely tracks investigations and evidence while maintaining strict chain-of-custody records for academic and cybersecurity use cases.

title: Digital Forensics Case Management and Evidence Tracking System
overview: This project focuses on building a digital forensics case management platform designed to support cybersecurity investigations in academic and enterprise environments. The system allows investigators to create cases, document investigation steps, upload and catalog digital evidence, and maintain strict chain-of-custody records. Evidence items are timestamped, hashed, and linked to specific cases to ensure integrity and accountability throughout the investigation lifecycle. The platform also supports report generation for legal or academic review and includes role-based permissions to restrict access to sensitive case data. Through this project, students gain hands-on experience with forensic workflows, evidence handling principles, and secure system design.
key_features: Case creation and investigation workflow tracking
Digital evidence upload with hashing and timestamps
Chain-of-custody logging for all evidence actions
Role-based access control for investigators and reviewers
Automated case report generation

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring evidence integrity throughout the investigation process
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented cryptographic hashing and immutable audit logs for evidence actions

challenges_solutions.challenge: Managing sensitive data with strict access requirements
challenges_solutions.solution: Applied fine-grained role-based permissions and secure storage practices

achievements: Demonstrated secure chain-of-custody handling during mock investigations
Produced audit-ready forensic reports
Used as a teaching tool in cybersecurity forensics coursework
short_description: A digital forensics case management system that securely tracks investigations and evidence while maintaining strict chain-of-custody records for academic and cybersecurity use cases.

title: Lightweight ERP System for Departmental Resource Planning
overview: This project involves the design and implementation of a lightweight Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system tailored specifically for academic departments within the university. The platform focuses on managing core departmental operations such as course scheduling, faculty workload planning, equipment reservations, and budget tracking. Unlike full-scale commercial ERP systems, this solution emphasizes simplicity, usability, and adaptability to academic workflows. The system integrates multiple functional modules into a unified interface, allowing department administrators and faculty leaders to make informed planning decisions based on real-time data. This project demonstrates how information systems principles can be applied to streamline organizational processes and improve operational transparency.
key_features: Course and schedule planning module
Faculty workload and assignment tracking
Departmental resource and equipment reservations
Basic budgeting and expense tracking
Unified dashboard for administrative oversight

challenges_solutions.challenge: Avoiding feature overload while meeting diverse departmental needs
challenges_solutions.solution: Conducted stakeholder interviews and prioritized high-impact core features

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring data consistency across multiple functional modules
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented a centralized data model with shared services

achievements: Streamlined departmental planning workflows
Reduced reliance on spreadsheets for administrative tasks
Demonstrated successful integration of multiple operational modules
short_description: A lightweight ERP system designed for academic departments to manage scheduling, faculty workload, resources, and budgeting through a unified and user-friendly platform.

title: Secure Access Management System for Academic IT Services
overview: This project focuses on designing and implementing a secure access management system tailored for academic IT services within the Department of Computing. The platform centralizes authentication and authorization for applications such as project repositories, lab systems, and administrative tools. It supports role-based access control for students, faculty, advisors, and administrators, ensuring users can only access resources appropriate to their roles. The system also includes auditing and logging features to track access events and support security reviews. Emphasis is placed on usability, security best practices, and integration with existing campus identity systems, demonstrating how access management improves both security posture and operational efficiency.
key_features: Centralized authentication and authorization
Role-based access control for academic users
Audit logs for access and permission changes
Integration-ready architecture for campus systems
Secure session and credential handling

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing strong security controls with ease of use
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented role-based policies with clear permission boundaries and simple user flows

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring auditability without excessive logging overhead
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed configurable logging levels and retention policies

achievements: Improved access control consistency across academic systems
Provided detailed audit trails for security reviews
Demonstrated secure authentication workflows during evaluation
short_description: A secure access management system that centralizes authentication and role-based authorization for academic IT services, improving security, auditability, and user experience.

title: Web-Based Capstone Project Management and Collaboration Portal
overview: This project involves the development of a web-based portal designed to support the management and collaboration needs of capstone project teams within the Department of Computing. The platform provides structured workflows for project proposal submission, milestone tracking, document sharing, and faculty feedback. Students can manage tasks, upload deliverables, and communicate progress updates, while faculty advisors can review submissions, provide comments, and monitor team performance over time. The system is designed to improve transparency, accountability, and coordination throughout the capstone lifecycle. This project emphasizes full-stack web development, user-centered design, and the application of software engineering best practices in an academic setting.
key_features: Project proposal and milestone management
Team collaboration and document sharing
Faculty review and feedback workflows
Progress tracking and status indicators
Role-based access for students and advisors

challenges_solutions.challenge: Coordinating project activities across multiple teams and advisors
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented structured milestones and role-based dashboards to clarify responsibilities

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring usability for both technical and non-technical users
challenges_solutions.solution: Conducted usability testing and iterated on interface design based on feedback

achievements: Improved communication between student teams and faculty advisors
Standardized capstone project workflows across multiple courses
Successfully used by several capstone teams during pilot semester
short_description: A web-based portal that supports capstone project management and collaboration by enabling proposal submission, milestone tracking, document sharing, and structured faculty feedback.

title: Phishing Simulation and Security Awareness Training Platform
overview: This project develops a cybersecurity training platform that helps organizations measure and improve user awareness against phishing attacks. The system allows administrators to design and launch simulated phishing campaigns to target groups of users with realistic email scenarios. It tracks key engagement metrics such as email opens, link clicks, credential submission attempts, and report rates. After each campaign, users receive just-in-time training content tailored to the scenario they encountered, reinforcing best practices for identifying suspicious messages. The platform also provides analytics dashboards for security teams to monitor risk trends by department and evaluate training effectiveness over time. The goal of this project is to reduce human-centered security vulnerabilities by combining measurable simulations with targeted education.
key_features: Configurable phishing simulation campaigns and templates
User targeting groups and scheduled campaign launches
Metrics tracking (opens, clicks, reports, submissions)
Just-in-time training modules after simulations
Analytics dashboard for risk and progress reporting

challenges_solutions.challenge: Making simulated emails realistic without increasing harm or confusion
challenges_solutions.solution: Used clear internal labeling for administrators and safe landing pages for users with immediate education

challenges_solutions.challenge: Tracking engagement accurately while respecting privacy
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented anonymized reporting options and role-based access for campaign results

achievements: Improved phishing awareness scores in simulated training scenarios
Delivered actionable risk analytics for administrators
Successfully ran multi-group campaigns during pilot testing
short_description: A phishing simulation and security awareness platform that runs realistic training campaigns, tracks user engagement metrics, and delivers targeted education to help reduce human-centered security risks.

title: Natural Language Processing System for Analyzing Student Feedback
overview: This project applies natural language processing (NLP) techniques to analyze large volumes of student feedback collected through course evaluations, surveys, and open-ended questionnaires. The system ingests textual responses and performs tasks such as sentiment analysis, topic modeling, and keyword extraction to uncover common themes and trends across courses and academic years. Faculty and administrators can use the resulting insights to better understand student experiences, identify areas for improvement, and track changes in sentiment over time. The project emphasizes practical NLP workflows, data preprocessing, model evaluation, and the ethical handling of sensitive educational data.
key_features: Text preprocessing and cleaning pipelines
Sentiment analysis of student feedback
Topic modeling to identify recurring themes
Trend analysis across courses and academic years
Dashboards for visualizing insights and summaries

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling noisy and unstructured student-written text
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented robust preprocessing steps including tokenization, lemmatization, and stop-word removal

challenges_solutions.challenge: Interpreting model outputs in a way meaningful to educators
challenges_solutions.solution: Mapped NLP results to clear visual summaries and human-readable themes

achievements: Identified recurring themes across thousands of feedback responses
Provided actionable insights for course improvement discussions
Demonstrated ethical handling of sensitive student data
short_description: An NLP-based analytics system that processes student feedback to extract sentiment, key themes, and trends, helping faculty and administrators make data-informed improvements.

title: Cloud-Based Virtual Lab Environment for Computing Courses
overview: This project delivers a cloud-based virtual lab environment designed to support hands-on learning in computing courses without requiring students to install complex software locally. The platform provisions isolated virtual lab instances on demand, preconfigured with course-specific tools, datasets, and development environments. Instructors can define lab templates, control access windows, and monitor usage, while students can launch labs from a web interface and resume work across sessions. By leveraging cloud infrastructure, the system improves accessibility, reduces setup time, and ensures consistency across learning environments. The project highlights practical cloud computing concepts, virtualization, and scalable system design for educational use cases.
key_features: On-demand provisioning of virtual lab environments
Preconfigured lab templates for different courses
Web-based access with session persistence
Instructor controls for access windows and monitoring
Scalable cloud infrastructure for concurrent users

challenges_solutions.challenge: Managing cost while supporting multiple simultaneous lab sessions
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented automatic shutdown policies and resource quotas per user

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring consistent lab environments across courses and semesters
challenges_solutions.solution: Used versioned lab templates and automated provisioning scripts

achievements: Reduced student setup time for lab-based courses
Improved consistency of lab environments across sections
Supported multiple courses during pilot deployment
short_description: A cloud-based virtual lab platform that provides on-demand, preconfigured computing environments for students, improving accessibility and consistency in hands-on coursework.

title: Role-Based Access and Audit System for Academic Information Systems
overview: This project focuses on enhancing security and accountability within academic information systems by implementing a role-based access control (RBAC) and auditing platform. The system manages user permissions for applications handling sensitive academic data such as student records, course registrations, and internal reports. It ensures that users can only access data and actions appropriate to their roles, such as student, faculty, advisor, or administrator. In addition, the platform records detailed audit logs of access events and changes, enabling administrators to review activity, investigate incidents, and demonstrate compliance with institutional policies. The project highlights the importance of governance, security controls, and transparency in information systems used in educational environments.
key_features: Role-based access control for academic applications
Centralized permission management
Detailed audit logging of user actions
Searchable and filterable audit reports
Administrative dashboards for access reviews

challenges_solutions.challenge: Designing roles flexible enough to support diverse academic workflows
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented hierarchical roles with configurable permission sets

challenges_solutions.challenge: Capturing meaningful audit data without overwhelming administrators
challenges_solutions.solution: Provided filtered views and summary reports for audit logs

achievements: Improved access control consistency across academic systems
Enabled transparent review of data access activities
Used as a reference model for secure academic applications
short_description: A role-based access and audit platform that secures academic information systems while providing transparent, searchable logs of user activity for compliance and governance.

title: High-Performance Database Optimization for Research Data Workloads
overview: This project investigates database optimization strategies for handling large-scale research datasets generated by computing and data-driven projects. The system evaluates query performance, indexing strategies, and data modeling techniques to improve response times and scalability under heavy analytical workloads. A test platform was built to simulate real research use cases, including complex joins, aggregations, and time-based queries. The project compares relational and document-based approaches, analyzes trade-offs, and provides recommendations for selecting appropriate database architectures in academic research environments. Emphasis is placed on performance tuning, monitoring, and evidence-based optimization decisions.
key_features: Benchmarking of database query performance
Indexing and query optimization strategies
Comparison of relational and document databases
Monitoring dashboards for performance metrics
Reusable test datasets and workloads

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing query performance with schema flexibility
challenges_solutions.solution: Evaluated hybrid modeling approaches and optimized indexes per workload type

challenges_solutions.challenge: Reproducing realistic research data access patterns
challenges_solutions.solution: Generated synthetic workloads based on actual research query logs

achievements: Reduced average query latency under heavy workloads
Produced clear guidelines for database selection in research projects
Demonstrated measurable performance improvements through indexing
short_description: A research-focused project that evaluates and optimizes database performance for large analytical workloads, providing practical guidance on indexing, query tuning, and database architecture choices.

title: Network Intrusion Detection and Traffic Analysis System
overview: This project focuses on designing and implementing a network intrusion detection and traffic analysis system to identify malicious activity and policy violations within enterprise and campus networks. The platform captures network traffic metadata and applies rule-based detection techniques alongside statistical analysis to flag suspicious patterns such as port scanning, brute-force attempts, and abnormal traffic spikes. Administrators can review alerts, inspect traffic summaries, and analyze trends over time to better understand network behavior and potential threats. The project emphasizes hands-on cybersecurity skills, including network monitoring, intrusion detection concepts, and secure system deployment.
key_features: Real-time network traffic monitoring
Rule-based intrusion detection alerts
Traffic analysis and trend visualization
Configurable alert thresholds
Historical traffic and incident reporting

challenges_solutions.challenge: Reducing false positives while maintaining effective detection
challenges_solutions.solution: Tuned detection rules using baseline traffic patterns and threshold adjustments

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling high volumes of network traffic data efficiently
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented traffic aggregation and sampling techniques

achievements: Successfully detected simulated intrusion attempts
Provided actionable network security insights
Used as a teaching aid in cybersecurity networking courses
short_description: A network intrusion detection and traffic analysis system that monitors network activity, detects suspicious behavior, and provides actionable security insights for administrators.

title: Time-Series Analysis Platform for Campus Energy Consumption
overview: This project applies time-series analysis techniques to study and forecast energy consumption patterns across campus buildings. The system ingests historical energy usage data from smart meters and facility management systems, cleans and normalizes the data, and applies statistical and machine learning models to identify trends, seasonal effects, and anomalies. Forecasting results help facilities planners anticipate peak demand periods, evaluate energy efficiency initiatives, and support sustainability planning. Interactive dashboards allow users to explore consumption patterns by building, time period, and energy type, demonstrating how data science can inform operational and environmental decision-making.
key_features: Time-series data ingestion and preprocessing
Trend, seasonality, and anomaly detection
Energy consumption forecasting models
Interactive dashboards by building and time range
Exportable reports for sustainability planning

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling missing or inconsistent sensor data
challenges_solutions.solution: Applied interpolation and smoothing techniques to maintain data continuity

challenges_solutions.challenge: Selecting appropriate forecasting models for different usage patterns
challenges_solutions.solution: Compared multiple time-series models and validated performance using backtesting

achievements: Accurately forecasted peak energy demand periods
Identified seasonal consumption patterns across campus buildings
Supported data-driven sustainability discussions
short_description: A time-series analytics platform that analyzes and forecasts campus energy consumption, helping planners understand trends, predict demand, and support sustainability initiatives.

title: Automated System Monitoring and Alerting Platform for Academic Labs
overview: This project involves the development of an automated system monitoring and alerting platform designed to support the reliability and availability of academic computer labs. The system continuously monitors key system metrics such as CPU usage, memory consumption, disk health, and service uptime across multiple lab machines. When predefined thresholds are exceeded or services become unavailable, the platform generates alerts for IT staff via dashboards and notifications. Historical monitoring data is retained to support trend analysis, capacity planning, and post-incident reviews. The project demonstrates practical system administration concepts and highlights the importance of proactive monitoring in maintaining stable computing environments.
key_features: Real-time monitoring of system health metrics
Configurable alert thresholds and notifications
Centralized dashboard for lab system status
Historical data retention for trend analysis
Support for multiple lab environments

challenges_solutions.challenge: Monitoring a large number of systems without excessive overhead
challenges_solutions.solution: Used lightweight agents and centralized data aggregation to minimize impact

challenges_solutions.challenge: Avoiding alert fatigue for IT staff
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented severity levels and alert suppression rules

achievements: Improved response time to lab system outages
Provided historical insight into system performance issues
Adopted as a reference project for system administration coursework
short_description: An automated monitoring and alerting platform that tracks system health across academic computer labs, enabling proactive issue detection and improved operational reliability.

title: Augmented Reality Learning Application for Computer Science Concepts
overview: This project explores the use of augmented reality (AR) to enhance the teaching and learning of abstract computer science concepts such as data structures, algorithms, and system architecture. The application overlays interactive 3D visualizations onto the physical environment, allowing students to explore concepts like trees, graphs, memory allocation, and process scheduling in an intuitive and engaging way. Users can manipulate virtual objects, step through algorithm executions, and observe changes in real time. The project demonstrates how immersive technologies can improve comprehension, engagement, and retention in computing education.
key_features: Interactive AR visualizations of computer science concepts
Step-by-step algorithm execution in 3D space
User interaction with virtual data structures
Cross-platform support for mobile devices
Educational modules aligned with course topics

challenges_solutions.challenge: Representing abstract concepts clearly in a 3D environment
challenges_solutions.solution: Worked closely with instructors to design intuitive visual metaphors

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring performance on a range of mobile devices
challenges_solutions.solution: Optimized 3D assets and used level-of-detail techniques

achievements: Improved student engagement in pilot classroom sessions
Received positive feedback on concept clarity and interactivity
Demonstrated potential for AR in computing education
short_description: An augmented reality learning application that visualizes computer science concepts in 3D, helping students better understand algorithms and data structures through interactive exploration.

title: User-Centered Redesign of Academic Advising Information Systems
overview: This project applies human–computer interaction (HCI) principles to redesign an existing academic advising information system used by students and faculty. The goal of the project was to improve usability, accessibility, and overall user satisfaction by addressing pain points identified in the legacy system. The team conducted user interviews, usability testing, and task analysis to understand how students and advisors interact with the system during course planning and advising sessions. Based on these findings, the project delivered a redesigned interface with simplified navigation, clearer information hierarchy, and improved feedback mechanisms. This work demonstrates how user-centered design can significantly enhance the effectiveness of information systems in academic environments.
key_features: User research through interviews and usability testing
Redesigned navigation and information architecture
Improved accessibility and visual clarity
Task-focused workflows for advising sessions
Prototype testing and iterative refinement

challenges_solutions.challenge: Understanding diverse user needs across students and advisors
challenges_solutions.solution: Conducted persona development and scenario-based usability testing

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing new design ideas with existing system constraints
challenges_solutions.solution: Delivered a modular redesign that could be incrementally adopted

achievements: Significantly improved usability scores during testing
Reduced task completion time for common advising workflows
Provided design recommendations adopted by stakeholders
short_description: A user-centered redesign of an academic advising information system that improves usability, accessibility, and efficiency through research-driven interface and workflow improvements.

title: Responsive Departmental Website Modernization and CMS Integration
overview: This project focuses on modernizing an outdated departmental website by redesigning it with a responsive, mobile-first approach and integrating a content management system (CMS) to simplify ongoing updates. The platform improves information architecture, accessibility, and performance while enabling non-technical staff to manage content such as announcements, faculty profiles, research highlights, and course information. The project emphasizes usability, accessibility standards (WCAG), and maintainable front-end architecture, demonstrating how thoughtful web design and CMS integration can significantly enhance communication and engagement for academic departments.
key_features: Responsive, mobile-first website redesign
Improved information architecture and navigation
CMS integration for easy content updates
Accessibility improvements aligned with WCAG guidelines
Performance optimization for faster load times

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing design flexibility with ease of content management
challenges_solutions.solution: Selected and configured a CMS with structured content models and reusable templates

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring accessibility across diverse content types
challenges_solutions.solution: Applied consistent accessibility checks and semantic HTML throughout the site

achievements: Improved mobile usability and accessibility compliance
Reduced time required for routine content updates
Positive feedback from faculty and administrative staff
short_description: A responsive redesign of a departmental website with CMS integration, improving accessibility, usability, and ease of content management for academic staff.

title: Personalized Course Recommendation System Using Student Performance Data
overview: This project develops a data-driven recommendation system that assists students in selecting courses aligned with their academic performance, interests, and degree progress. The system analyzes historical course outcomes, prerequisite structures, and student performance patterns to generate personalized course suggestions. By leveraging collaborative filtering and content-based recommendation techniques, the platform identifies courses where students are likely to succeed while also encouraging timely degree completion. Advisors can use the system to support academic planning discussions, while students gain clearer insight into course options and potential academic pathways. The project demonstrates applied data science techniques in an educational context, with a focus on interpretability and ethical use of student data.
key_features: Personalized course recommendations based on performance data
Analysis of prerequisite and degree requirement structures
Advisor dashboards for reviewing recommendation rationale
Student-facing views explaining suggested courses
Evaluation metrics to assess recommendation effectiveness

challenges_solutions.challenge: Avoiding biased recommendations based on limited historical data
challenges_solutions.solution: Combined collaborative filtering with content-based methods and enforced diversity constraints

challenges_solutions.challenge: Making recommendations understandable to students and advisors
challenges_solutions.solution: Provided explanation layers showing factors influencing each recommendation

achievements: Improved course planning confidence among pilot student group
Provided advisors with data-backed planning support
Demonstrated responsible use of academic performance data
short_description: A personalized course recommendation system that analyzes student performance and degree requirements to suggest courses that support academic success and timely graduation.

title: Digital Document Management System for Academic Departments
overview: This project involves the design and implementation of a digital document management system tailored for academic departments to securely store, organize, and retrieve important documents. The system supports version control, metadata tagging, and role-based access to ensure documents such as syllabi, accreditation materials, meeting minutes, and policy files are easily accessible while remaining secure. Advanced search capabilities allow users to quickly locate documents by keyword, date, department, or document type. The platform also tracks document history and changes to support accountability and compliance requirements. This project demonstrates core information systems concepts including data governance, usability, and secure information management.
key_features: Centralized document storage and organization
Version control and document history tracking
Metadata tagging and advanced search
Role-based access for faculty and administrators
Secure document sharing and auditing

challenges_solutions.challenge: Preventing unauthorized access to sensitive documents
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented role-based permissions and secure authentication workflows

challenges_solutions.challenge: Managing document versions without user confusion
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed clear version labeling and change history views

achievements: Improved organization and retrieval of departmental documents
Reduced reliance on email-based document sharing
Supported compliance and accreditation preparation workflows
short_description: A secure digital document management system that enables academic departments to store, organize, and retrieve important files with version control, search, and role-based access.

title: Incident Response Simulation and Training Platform
overview: This project delivers a hands-on incident response (IR) simulation platform designed to train students in practical cybersecurity response workflows. The system presents realistic attack scenarios—such as ransomware outbreaks, data exfiltration, and insider threats—and guides users through structured response phases including detection, containment, eradication, recovery, and post-incident review. Participants make decisions in real time, document actions taken, and receive feedback on effectiveness and adherence to best practices. Faculty can configure scenarios, track participant progress, and assess learning outcomes. The project emphasizes experiential learning, teamwork, and the application of established incident response frameworks.
key_features: Configurable incident response simulation scenarios
Step-by-step IR workflow guidance and documentation
Real-time decision tracking and scoring
Instructor dashboards for scenario management
Post-incident reports and learning feedback

challenges_solutions.challenge: Designing realistic scenarios without overwhelming participants
challenges_solutions.solution: Introduced progressive scenario complexity and contextual hints

challenges_solutions.challenge: Objectively evaluating participant decisions
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented rubric-based scoring aligned with IR frameworks

achievements: Improved student preparedness for real-world incident response
Adopted as a lab component in cybersecurity coursework
Provided measurable assessment of IR decision-making skills
short_description: A simulation-based training platform that immerses students in realistic cybersecurity incident response scenarios, strengthening practical decision-making and response skills.

title: Operating System Scheduling Simulator for Performance Analysis
overview: This project focuses on building an interactive operating system scheduling simulator that allows students to explore and compare different CPU scheduling algorithms under varying workloads. The platform supports common scheduling strategies such as First-Come First-Served (FCFS), Shortest Job First (SJF), Priority Scheduling, and Round Robin. Users can configure process arrival times, burst durations, and priorities, then observe how each algorithm affects metrics such as waiting time, turnaround time, and CPU utilization. Visual timelines and charts help illustrate scheduling behavior, making abstract OS concepts more concrete. The project emphasizes systems programming concepts, algorithm analysis, and educational visualization.
key_features: Simulation of multiple CPU scheduling algorithms
Configurable process workloads and parameters
Visual timelines and performance charts
Comparison of scheduling metrics across algorithms
Educational interface for systems learning

challenges_solutions.challenge: Clearly visualizing complex scheduling behavior
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed step-by-step timeline animations with synchronized metric updates

challenges_solutions.challenge: Ensuring accuracy of performance calculations
challenges_solutions.solution: Validated results against textbook examples and test cases

achievements: Improved student understanding of OS scheduling concepts
Used as a supplemental learning tool in operating systems courses
Demonstrated clear comparisons of algorithm performance
short_description: An interactive operating system scheduling simulator that visualizes CPU scheduling algorithms and compares their performance metrics to support systems education.

title: Geospatial Data Analytics Platform for Urban Planning Insights
overview: This project develops a geospatial data analytics platform that leverages geographic information system (GIS) data to support urban planning and infrastructure analysis. The system integrates spatial datasets such as population density, land use, transportation networks, and public services, enabling users to explore spatial relationships and patterns through interactive maps and visualizations. Analytical tools allow planners and researchers to identify underserved areas, assess infrastructure accessibility, and evaluate the potential impact of development initiatives. The project demonstrates how data science techniques combined with geospatial analysis can inform evidence-based planning and policy decisions.
key_features: Integration of multiple geospatial datasets
Interactive map-based visualizations
Spatial analysis tools for accessibility and coverage
Filtering and comparison by region and time
Exportable insights for planning reports

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling large geospatial datasets efficiently
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented spatial indexing and optimized data queries

challenges_solutions.challenge: Presenting complex spatial data to non-technical users
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed intuitive map layers and guided analysis workflows

achievements: Enabled spatial insights for simulated urban planning scenarios
Demonstrated effective integration of GIS and data analytics
Used as a reference project for geospatial data courses
short_description: A geospatial analytics platform that combines GIS data and data science techniques to support urban planning and infrastructure decision-making through interactive maps and spatial analysis.

title: IT Service Automation Platform for Helpdesk and Support Operations
overview: This project focuses on automating common IT helpdesk and support workflows to improve response times and reduce manual effort in academic IT environments. The platform streamlines ticket intake, categorization, assignment, and resolution tracking by integrating automation rules and self-service options. Users can submit requests through a web interface, while IT staff benefit from automated routing, status updates, and performance metrics. The system also includes a knowledge base that suggests solutions to users before tickets are escalated, helping to resolve routine issues faster. This project highlights how automation can enhance service quality, operational efficiency, and user satisfaction in IT support operations.
key_features: Automated ticket intake and categorization
Rule-based assignment and escalation workflows
Self-service knowledge base for common issues
Real-time ticket status tracking
Analytics and reporting on support performance

challenges_solutions.challenge: Accurately categorizing diverse support requests
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented keyword-based classification with manual override options

challenges_solutions.challenge: Encouraging users to adopt self-service features
challenges_solutions.solution: Integrated contextual help suggestions during ticket submission

achievements: Reduced average helpdesk response times during pilot use
Improved visibility into support workload and trends
Demonstrated effective automation of routine IT tasks
short_description: An IT service automation platform that streamlines helpdesk workflows, improves response times, and enhances support efficiency through automated ticket handling and self-service tools.

title: Secure Code Analysis and Vulnerability Detection Platform
overview: This project focuses on building a secure code analysis platform that helps identify common software vulnerabilities during the development lifecycle. The system analyzes source code repositories to detect issues such as insecure input handling, improper authentication logic, and misconfigured security controls. By combining static analysis techniques with rule-based detection, the platform provides developers with actionable feedback before applications are deployed. Results are presented through a clear dashboard that highlights risk severity, affected files, and recommended remediation steps. The project emphasizes secure software engineering practices and demonstrates how early vulnerability detection can reduce long-term security risk.
key_features: Static source code analysis for security vulnerabilities
Rule-based detection of common coding flaws
Severity scoring and prioritization of findings
Developer-friendly dashboards and reports
Guidance for secure remediation practices

challenges_solutions.challenge: Reducing false positives in automated code analysis
challenges_solutions.solution: Refined detection rules and added contextual checks to improve accuracy

challenges_solutions.challenge: Making security findings understandable to student developers
challenges_solutions.solution: Included clear explanations and examples for each detected issue

achievements: Detected security flaws in sample student applications
Improved awareness of secure coding practices
Used as a learning aid in secure software courses
short_description: A secure code analysis platform that scans source code for common vulnerabilities and provides actionable feedback to help developers adopt safer coding practices.

title: Knowledge Management Portal for Research Labs and Faculty Collaboration
overview: This project builds a knowledge management portal designed to help research labs and faculty teams capture, organize, and reuse institutional knowledge across semesters and project cycles. The platform addresses a common problem in academic environments: valuable knowledge gets lost when students graduate, teams change, or documentation is scattered across emails and personal drives. The system provides structured spaces for labs and faculty groups to store project artifacts, meeting notes, research protocols, onboarding guides, and reusable templates. Content is organized using metadata tags, versioning, and role-based access so that teams can securely share information while keeping sensitive work protected. The portal also supports advanced search, linking related resources, and “knowledge handoff” summaries that help new members quickly understand context. The project highlights information systems best practices in governance, collaboration workflows, and long-term knowledge retention.
key_features: Structured knowledge base for labs and faculty teams
Metadata tagging, versioning, and content organization
Role-based access control and secure sharing
Advanced search with filters and relevance ranking
Onboarding and knowledge-handoff pages for continuity

challenges_solutions.challenge: Keeping documentation consistent across different research groups and workflows
challenges_solutions.solution: Introduced reusable templates, required metadata fields, and guided content creation flows

challenges_solutions.challenge: Helping users find the right information quickly as the repository grows
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented structured tagging, indexed search fields, and a related-content linking model

achievements: Improved continuity for research labs by reducing onboarding time for new members
Centralized scattered documentation into a searchable and organized portal
Provided structured workflows for long-term academic knowledge retention
short_description: A knowledge management portal that helps research labs and faculty teams capture, organize, and reuse documentation, protocols, and project artifacts with secure access, versioning, and powerful search for long-term continuity.

title: Network Intrusion Detection and Monitoring System for Academic Environments
overview: This project designs and implements a network intrusion detection and monitoring system tailored for academic and research network environments. The system focuses on identifying suspicious traffic patterns, unauthorized access attempts, and anomalous behavior that could indicate security threats. By collecting and analyzing network logs and packet metadata, the platform applies rule-based detection and behavioral thresholds to flag potential intrusions in near real time. A centralized dashboard allows administrators and students to visualize alerts, traffic trends, and risk levels across different network segments. The project emphasizes practical cybersecurity skills, including network security monitoring, incident awareness, and defensive strategy development in a controlled academic context.
key_features: Real-time monitoring of network traffic and events
Rule-based intrusion detection and alerting
Visualization of network activity and security alerts
Configurable thresholds for anomaly detection
Centralized dashboard for security awareness

challenges_solutions.challenge: Distinguishing normal academic network activity from malicious behavior
challenges_solutions.solution: Defined baseline traffic patterns and tuned detection rules using historical data

challenges_solutions.challenge: Presenting security alerts without overwhelming users
challenges_solutions.solution: Introduced severity levels and grouped related alerts into incidents

achievements: Demonstrated effective detection of simulated intrusion scenarios
Improved understanding of network security monitoring concepts
Used as a reference project for cybersecurity coursework
short_description: A network intrusion detection and monitoring system that analyzes traffic patterns and logs to identify suspicious activity and improve security awareness in academic network environments.

title: Intelligent Academic Recommendation System for Student Course Planning
overview: This project develops an intelligent recommendation system designed to assist students with academic course planning and decision-making. The system analyzes historical enrollment data, degree requirements, prerequisite structures, and student performance trends to recommend optimal course sequences tailored to individual academic goals. By incorporating rule-based logic alongside basic machine learning techniques, the platform adapts recommendations based on a student’s progress, interests, and workload preferences. The project demonstrates how artificial intelligence can be applied responsibly in educational settings to improve advising efficiency and student outcomes while maintaining transparency and explainability.
key_features: Personalized course recommendations based on academic history
Prerequisite and degree requirement validation
Adaptive suggestions based on workload and performance
Explainable recommendation logic for transparency
Advisor-facing insights for academic planning support

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing recommendation accuracy with transparency
challenges_solutions.solution: Combined rule-based logic with lightweight machine learning and clear explanations

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling incomplete or inconsistent student data
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented fallback rules and confidence thresholds for recommendations

achievements: Improved sample advising scenarios through personalized recommendations
Demonstrated ethical and explainable AI use in education
Referenced in academic advising technology discussions
short_description: An intelligent academic recommendation system that helps students plan course sequences using explainable AI and rule-based logic to support informed academic decision-making.

title: Cloud-Based Infrastructure Monitoring and Cost Optimization System
overview: This project focuses on designing a cloud-based infrastructure monitoring and cost optimization system aimed at helping organizations better understand and manage their cloud resource usage. The platform collects metrics from virtual machines, storage services, and network components to provide real-time visibility into system performance and operational costs. Users can view dashboards that highlight underutilized resources, usage spikes, and cost trends over time. The system also generates recommendations for cost optimization, such as rightsizing instances or scheduling non-critical workloads during off-peak hours. This project demonstrates practical information technology skills related to cloud management, monitoring, and cost-aware system design.
key_features: Real-time monitoring of cloud infrastructure metrics
Cost tracking and usage visualization
Identification of underutilized or overprovisioned resources
Automated cost-optimization recommendations
Historical reporting and trend analysis

challenges_solutions.challenge: Aggregating metrics from multiple cloud services
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented a unified data collection layer with normalized metrics

challenges_solutions.challenge: Presenting cost data in an actionable way
challenges_solutions.solution: Designed dashboards that pair cost insights with concrete optimization suggestions

achievements: Identified cost-saving opportunities in simulated cloud environments
Improved visibility into cloud usage patterns
Demonstrated practical cloud management and optimization techniques
short_description: A cloud infrastructure monitoring and cost optimization system that provides real-time insights into resource usage and helps identify opportunities to reduce operational cloud costs.

title: Predictive Analytics System for Student Retention and Success
overview: This project develops a predictive analytics system aimed at identifying patterns and risk factors associated with student retention and academic success. Using historical academic records, enrollment data, and engagement indicators, the system applies statistical analysis and machine learning models to forecast potential retention challenges. The goal is to support advisors and administrators by providing early insights that enable proactive interventions, such as targeted advising or academic support. The platform emphasizes responsible data use, model transparency, and interpretability to ensure predictions can be understood and trusted by non-technical stakeholders. This project demonstrates how data science can be applied ethically to improve educational outcomes.
key_features: Predictive models for identifying retention risk
Analysis of academic and engagement indicators
Explainable model outputs for advisor interpretation
Dashboards highlighting trends and risk factors
Scenario-based insights for intervention planning

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing predictive accuracy with interpretability
challenges_solutions.solution: Selected models that provide clear feature importance and human-readable explanations

challenges_solutions.challenge: Handling sensitive academic data responsibly
challenges_solutions.solution: Applied data anonymization and access controls throughout the system

achievements: Demonstrated early identification of at-risk student profiles
Highlighted ethical considerations in educational data analytics
Referenced in discussions on data-informed advising strategies
short_description: A predictive analytics system that uses academic and engagement data to identify student retention risks and support proactive, data-informed advising interventions.

title: Cybersecurity Policy Compliance and Risk Assessment Dashboard
overview: This project develops a cybersecurity policy compliance and risk assessment dashboard to help organizations evaluate their adherence to established security standards and internal policies. The system allows administrators to map technical controls and operational practices against frameworks such as NIST and ISO-inspired guidelines adapted for academic environments. Users can conduct periodic assessments, document evidence, and track compliance gaps over time. The dashboard translates technical findings into risk scores and visual summaries that support decision-making by both technical staff and non-technical stakeholders. The project demonstrates how cybersecurity governance, risk management, and compliance (GRC) concepts can be operationalized through accessible software tools.
key_features: Policy-to-control mapping for compliance evaluation
Risk scoring based on identified gaps and control maturity
Evidence tracking and assessment history
Visual dashboards for compliance and risk posture
Exportable reports for audits and reviews

challenges_solutions.challenge: Making compliance requirements understandable to non-security users
challenges_solutions.solution: Used plain-language descriptions and visual indicators for each control

challenges_solutions.challenge: Balancing flexibility with consistency across assessments
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented standardized assessment templates with configurable sections

achievements: Demonstrated practical application of cybersecurity governance concepts
Provided clear visibility into compliance gaps and risk exposure
Used as a reference example in cybersecurity policy coursework
short_description: A cybersecurity policy compliance and risk assessment dashboard that helps organizations evaluate controls, identify gaps, and visualize risk posture using clear, non-technical insights.

title: Enterprise Reporting and Decision Support Dashboard
overview: This project focuses on building an enterprise reporting and decision support dashboard designed to help departments and administrators gain actionable insights from operational and academic data. The platform consolidates data from multiple sources such as enrollment systems, project tracking tools, and performance reports into a unified interface. Users can explore interactive dashboards that highlight key metrics, trends, and comparisons across time and departments. Emphasis was placed on data accuracy, consistency, and usability so that both technical and non-technical users could confidently rely on the system for decision-making. The project demonstrates core information systems principles including data integration, business intelligence, and user-centered dashboard design.
key_features: Centralized reporting from multiple data sources
Interactive dashboards with charts and filters
Role-based access to reports and metrics
Trend analysis and period comparisons
Exportable reports for presentations and planning

challenges_solutions.challenge: Integrating inconsistent data formats from different systems
challenges_solutions.solution: Implemented a data normalization layer to standardize incoming datasets

challenges_solutions.challenge: Designing dashboards that serve diverse user roles
challenges_solutions.solution: Created configurable views tailored to administrative and academic users

achievements: Improved visibility into departmental performance metrics
Demonstrated effective data integration and reporting workflows
Used as a sample project for business intelligence courses
short_description: An enterprise reporting and decision support dashboard that integrates data from multiple systems to provide clear, interactive insights for academic and administrative decision-making.

title: Interactive Data Visualization Platform for Research Insights
overview: This project delivers an interactive data visualization platform designed to help researchers and students explore complex datasets through intuitive visual representations. The system supports multiple chart types, dynamic filtering, and comparative views that allow users to uncover trends, correlations, and outliers across research data. Special attention was given to usability and visual clarity so that users without deep technical backgrounds could still gain meaningful insights. The platform also supports exporting visualizations for reports and presentations, making it suitable for academic research dissemination. This project highlights core computer science concepts in frontend engineering, data processing, and visualization design.
key_features: Interactive charts and graphs with dynamic filters
Support for multiple dataset formats
Comparative and trend analysis views
Exportable visualizations for reports
Responsive and accessible UI design
